docs.lead_paragraph: The Irish government announced plans this week for a national referendum on a constitutional amendment that would ban on abortion except in cases when woman would die by carrying her pregnancy to term. Flanked by his highest-ranking ministers and lieutenants, Prime Minister Bertie Ahern announced the plan Tuesday, on the eve of Parliament's opening session.

headline.main: Ireland Plans Referendum To Tighten Abortion Ban

docs.abstract: Irish government sets national referendum on constitutional ban on abortion, with exception only to save mother's life; proposal would not substantively alter Ireland's abortion laws, already some of world's most restrictive, but Prime Min Bertie Ahern says vote is needed because current law is based on Supreme Court decision, leaving it open to reinterpretation (M)
docs.snippet: The Irish government announced plans this week for a national referendum on a constitutional amendment that would ban on abortion except in cases when woman would die by carrying her pregnancy to term.    Flanked by his highest-ranking ministers and...

docs.lead_paragraph: An article in the Vital Signs column of Science Times on Tuesday about prayer and the success of in vitro fertilization misstated the title of the journal that published a study on the subject. It is The Journal of Reproductive Medicine, not Reproductive Health.
docs.abstract: Correction of Oct 2 report on prayer and in-vitro fertilization; study publication noted

docs.lead_paragraph: The Irish government announced plans to hold a national referendum before next spring on measures that will make it more difficult for women to have abortions. According to the outcome of a 1992 Supreme Court case, abortion is illegal in Ireland unless carrying the pregnancy to term threatens the mother's life, or if she threatens to commit suicide. The new proposal will create legislation to uphold that ban and will remove the suicide provision. Brian Lavery (NYT)

headline.main: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: A Vote On Tougher Abortion Laws

docs.abstract: Irish government announces plans to hold national referendum before spring 2002 on measures to make it more difficult for women to have abortions; 1992 Supreme Court decision outlawed abortion, except in cases in which carrying fetus to term threatens mother's life, or if she threatens to commit suicide; new proposal will create legislation to uphold ban and to remove suicide provision (S)
docs.snippet: The Irish government announced plans to hold a national referendum before next spring on measures that will make it more difficult for women to have abortions. According to the outcome of a 1992 Supreme Court case, abortion is illegal in Ireland...

docs.lead_paragraph: There is no evidence that thimerosal, a mercury-containing preservative formerly used in childhood vaccines, poses a significant threat to the developing brain, a panel of medical experts said yesterday. Nevertheless, in a report issued yesterday, the 15-member panel urged drug and vaccine manufacturers to redouble their efforts to remove mercury from all products used by children and pregnant women. The experts, appointed by the Institute of Medicine, said that although there was not enough evidence either to prove or disprove a link between the amounts of mercury in older vaccines and abnormal brain development, such a link was ''biologically plausible.''
docs.abstract: Report by panel of medical experts at Institute of Medicine says there is no evidence that thimerosal, mercury-containing preservative formerly used in childhood vaccines, poses significant threat to developing brain but warns drug and vaccine manufacturers should redouble efforts to remove mercury from all products used by children and pregnant women; says even though there is not enough evidence to either prove or disprove link between mercury in older vaccines and abnormal brain development, such link is 'biologically plausible' (M)
docs.snippet: There is no evidence that thimerosal, a mercury-containing preservative formerly used in childhood vaccines, poses a significant threat to the developing brain, a panel of medical experts said yesterday.    Nevertheless, in a report issued yesterday,...

docs.lead_paragraph: Researchers at Columbia University, expressing surprise at their own findings, are reporting that women at an in vitro fertilization clinic in Korea had a higher pregnancy rate when, unknown to the patients, total strangers were asked to pray for their success. The findings are in the current Journal of Reproductive Health.

headline.main: A Study Links Prayer and Pregnancy

docs.abstract: Columbia University researchers, surprised at own findings, report women at in vitro fertilization clinic in Korea had far higher pregnancy rate when, unknown to patients, total strangers were asked to pray for their success; had asked members of different Christian denominations abroad to pray for some of women; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Researchers at Columbia University, expressing surprise at their own findings, are reporting that women at an in vitro fertilization clinic in Korea had a higher pregnancy rate when, unknown to the patients, total strangers were asked to pray for...
